qas.question: What system was examined to develop the neurobiological explanation of human emotion?
What classification of chemicals do dopamine, serotonin and noradrenaline belong to?
Reactive responses are present in the brains of what animals?
The neurobiological explanation is specific to what types of brains?
What system wasn't examined to develop the neurobiological explanation of human emotion?
What classification of chemicals do dopamine, serotonin and noradrenaline not belong to?
What chemicals do not mediate emotions?
Reactive responses aren't present in the brains of what animals?
The neurobiological explanation isn't specific to what types of brains?

context: Based on discoveries made through neural mapping of the <a0_0>limbic<a0_0/> system, the neurobiological explanation of human emotion is that emotion is a pleasant or unpleasant mental state organized in the <b5_0>limbic<b5_0/> system of the <a4_0>mammalian<a4_0/> brain. If distinguished from reactive responses of <a3_0><b8_0>reptiles<b8_0/><a3_0/>, emotions would then be <b9_0>mammalian<b9_0/> elaborations of general vertebrate arousal patterns, in which <a1_0><b6_0>neurochemicals<b6_0/><a1_0/> (for example, dopamine, noradrenaline, and serotonin) step-up or step-down the brain's activity level, as visible in body movements, gestures and postures. Emotions can likely be mediated by <a2_0><b7_0>pheromones<b7_0/><a2_0/> (see fear).
